messageBody:
Mitchell:

I have found building reading speed in QS has been a bit of a problem as well.  I don't ascribe it to any flaw in the alphabet, however.  I have not tried to learn another alphabet, such as Greek or Cyrillic, as an adult so it is difficult to judge whether the problem could be connected to the fact that most of us are introduced to our language's writing system when quite young and, possibly, a child's mind is more malleable than an adult's, as is evidenced by children's alleged ease in learning language.  

But I believe it more likely that the heart of the problem lies in the limited amount of practice we get in reading QS.  From our birth we are surrounded by the ubiquity of the roman alphabet.  It is everywhere, and we see it constantly.  Our facility in reading it is so great that we read and comprehend the meaning even when we have no desire to, such as advertising on the side of a bus. QS is not ubiquitous.  Most of us using it primarily see our own QS rather than other people's.  If the people on this list communicated in QS, at least part of the time, I believe we would see an improvement in our ability to read QS.

We write one symbol at a time so it is easy to spell by sound in QS as we go.  However, we read in larger chunks, words at the minimum, or several words in a glance, if we are to read with any speed.  Obviously, the connection in the brain between the symbol and the sound must be one hundred percent solid so that no conscious thought is required.  Apparently, this takes lots of practice -- considerably more than most of us have given QS.  Think of the years you have spent reading TO before you conclude that QS is in some way deficient.

I am more proficient at reading QS now than I was in the past since I have spent more time at it recently, but it is still not as automatic as reading the traditional orthography (TO).  I almost feel as if I have to shift gears when I read it. But I am finding that I read whole words and more now than I used to since I started writing more in it.  I write notes in QS in my files and sometimes intersperse it with TO.  I have mentioned to my secretary that she should learn to read it, but she hasn't found the time yet.  My law partner (my father) has expressed some annoyment at my use of QS, which he expresses by noting "if you get hit by a truck, I won't be able to read these notes in your files."  I will have to convince my secretary to learn QS.  After all, they all used to learn shorthand and didn't complain.  Once she can read it, she can transliterate it for my father if the proverbial truck with my name on it appears.

 

Paige Gabhart



mitchell perilstein wrote:
On Fri, 2003-05-30 at 14:29, Robert McBroom wrote:
  
I agree that, for me too, QS has proven a write-only language.  I have
developed speed in writing, but reading speed seems not to have
improved in a year's work.  I'm glad to see that I'm not alone in this
phenomenon.  There must be two different parts of the brain at work
for coding, and uncoding the information.
    
I wonder if an orthography could be *designed* for ease of reading
first, with other concerns such as pen lifts and space secondary.

One thing that would definitely help would be to reduce the number of
glyphs which look similar when rotated or reversed.  Shavian has many of
these.  Read mentioned somewhere that reducing the number of these was a
goal for QS.  Perhaps a read-friendly orthography would have none of
them.

 - Mitch
